author: chfast
content: I noticed that "light" call failures also return `EXTCALL_REVERT`. are we should about it? Don't we want the "revert" to be only for "user programmable errors"?

author: pdobacz
content: IIRC it has been decided like this on one of the EOF calls, can't tell offhand the specific rationale, or when that was.

author: big_tech_sux
content: I think it was because of some edge cases in gas introspection

author: big_tech_sux
content: Like somehow if you get the other failure code, you can find out if you are at the end of the call stack or not

author: gumb00
content: I think rationale was REVERT doesn't consume all gas, similar to light failures

author: rodiazet
content: I made finally some simple execution benchmark for simple swap function on evmone. It's added to the doc I shared earlier https://notes.ethereum.org/@ipsilon/solidity_eof_poc

author: poojaranjan

author: marioevz
content: I'm trying to figure out why is evmone complaining about this test:

author: marioevz
content: It was passing on a previous commit, this is the only failing test for the set of tests in the main branch of EEST

author: _shemnon
content: I think they started enforcing initcode and runtime code sizes in validation

author: marioevz
content: It's generated based on this test: https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/blob/e80addbb8f1c973433bbf73158f801b312eedc58/tests/prague/eip7692_eof_v1/eip7620_eof_create/test_eofcreate_failures.py#L171

author: marioevz
content: but there is no data in either of the containers (I think)

author: _shemnon
content: It's the size of the top level container?

author: marioevz
content: It's > 0xFFFF

author: _shemnon
content: Right... it's the subcontainers I was testing here...

author: _shemnon
content: It's the total size of the subcontainer, cranked up to 64k. All code no data.

author: _shemnon
content: This blurs the line of testing what is possible and what is legal on mainnet.  The EOFCREATE call should fail as initcode > 48k and the returncontract call should also fail as deployed contract size > 24k.  Should it be enforced in container validation or at runtime?  Perhaps we should disable those tests for a week or two.

author: _shemnon
content: The ones greater than inticode and runtimecode size.

author: marioevz
content: I think we should not really add something to the pre that is impossible to deploy, we have some very specific scenarios to e.g. test for collisions but we are very careful when we write these

author: marioevz
content: But in this specific case, how is evmone even able to detect it comes from an impossible initcontainer? Or does it simply check for the container to be < 64k?

author: marioevz
content: I think we should not allow anything > 24k in the pre, but I donâ€™t really know if this is the case for existing tests tbh
